thread.title_full: FTSE 100’s triple-digit gain helps it rebound from Monday rout - MarketWatch

author: Carla Mozee
title: FTSE 100’s triple-digit gain helps it rebound from Monday rout
text:
Stocks in the U.K. ended sharply higher Thursday as shares of commodity producers lead a rally that’s helped the benchmark FTSE 100 to recover from a sharp selloff at the start of the week.
The FTSE 100 UKX, +3.56% jumped 212.83 points, or 3.6%, to 6,192.03, marking the biggest percentage gain since October 2011, FactSet data show.
The move pushed the blue-chips index slightly above where it stood before Monday’s rout , spurred by worries about slowing growth in China. That selloff left a number of major global stocks indexes, including the FTSE 100, down by at least 10% from their most recent or all-time highs.
Read: Some analysts are dismissing fears of a hard landing in China.
Resource shares: Mining and oil and gas companies put in the strongest performances Thursday, supported by a rally in prices for most metals and energy products. Oil prices CLV5, +9.59% surged more than 6% following a hefty upward revision in second-quarter U.S. gross domestic product , indicating economic activity in the world’s largest economy was more vigorous than previously thought.
Read : U.S. stocks surged further after the GDP report
The “report is a sizable step in the right direction, not only in terms of headline growth, but the composition of activity is much more favorable as well, albeit not quite as favorable as growth this time last year,” said Lindsey Piegza, chief economist at Stifel Fixed Income, in a note.
Oil major BP PLC BP., +6.04% BP, +5.98% tacked on 6%, Royal Dutch Shell PLC RDSB, +4.67% RDS.B, +3.60% rose 4.7% and BG Group PLC BG., +4.10% moved up 4.1%.
Among London-listed miners, iron ore producers Anglo American PLC AAL, +9.33% and BHP Billiton PLC BLT, +9.21% BHP, +5.49% BHP, +0.50% jumped 9.3% and 9.2%, respectively. Glencore PLC GLEN, +4.64% rose 4.6%.
Shares of resource companies make up about one-fifth of the FTSE 100’s weighting.
The pound GBPUSD, -0.3039% meanwhile, briefly fell below $1.54 during the session, before recovering back above that level later, as the bigger-than-expected 3.7% rate of U.S. GDP expansion pushed the U.S. dollar higher DXY, +0.45% against its rival.
Back on the FTSE 100, Barclays PLC BARC, +4.21% rose 4.2% after a U.S. federal judge on Wednesday dismissed a lawsuit against the banking heavyweight that alleged that it and U.S. stock exchanges defrauded investors in its dark pool, a private trading venue.
Whitbread PLC WTB, -0.91% which runs the Costa Coffee and Premier Inn hotel chains, was the only index member to have its shares lose ground, ending with a 0.9% loss.
